thread.title: Newcastle MP Nick Brown to continue as Jeremy Corbyn's chief whip

author: Keiran Southern
title: Newcastle MP Nick Brown to continue as Jeremy Corbyn's chief whip
text:
News Newcastle MP Nick Brown to continue as Jeremy Corbyn's chief whip Labour MP Mr Brown was re-elected to his Newcastle East seat with a landslide victory in the General Election Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Newcastle MP Nick Brown will continue in his role as Labour’s chief whip after the party defied expectations in the General Election. 
Mr Brown was re-elected to the Newcastle East seat he has occupied since 1983 with a significantly increased majority following Thursday’s vote. 
And on Friday Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn asked Mr Brown to continue as chief whip. Labour Candidate for Newcastle East, Nick Brown wins (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
He is in his third spell in the job, having served as the party’s chief whip under Gordon Brown when Labour was in power, and more recently under former leader Ed Miliband in opposition. 
Tynemouth MP Alan Campbell will serve as deputy chief whip. 
Mr Brown said: “I am more than happy to serve Jeremy. He had a wonderful campaign and a courageous one as well. 
“It was magnificent and there’s a real sense of energy about our side now. It is all very uplifting and we are looking forward to what lies ahead. 
“I think Jeremy has emphatically answered his critics. He has come through the campaign with flying colours. The Prime Minister called for stability but was unable to deliver it. (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
“Jeremy delivered stability. He has proved he is a safe pair of hands.” 
The chief whip is responsible for enforcing discipline within the Parliamentary Party. Read More UK Election 2017 results LIVE: Theresa May to form government with support from DUP despite election disaster 
Speaking shortly after he was re-elected, Mr Brown, said: “It really is quite exceptional. I am delighted and very proud that people I have represented for so long continue to put their trust in me. This is going to be a very, very difficult parliament because of Brexit. 
“So I feel the responsibility and will do my best to live up to the trust that is placed in me.” 
Mr Brown was Minister for the North East between 2007 and 2010. 
He has also served as a Farming Minister, Work and Pensions Minister and deputy chief whip. 
The MP was chief whip between 2008 and 2010, and shadow chief whip for five months in 2010. Like us on Facebook
